summary: On February 2, 2012, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered final judgments against Canatal Industries, Inc. and MCLO Structural Steel Corp. for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  According to the SEC's order, on February 13, 2008, Granite Building 2, LLC and Kulka Contracting, LLC were hired to hang wallpaper in a newly constructed office building that was nearly complete.  The SEC alleges that, on the morning of the accident, the defendants removed a portion of the fence meant to close off access to the parking deck to allow for a delivery truck to enter and then failed to replace the fence once the delivery truck entered.  In addition, the SEC further alleges that the defendants failed to show sufficient facts to establish that the work that they would have performed was part of the larger construction project.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, Canatal and Lalezarian have consented to the entry of final judgments that permanently restrains and enjoin them from future violations of the federal securities laws, and orders them to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties in amounts to be determined by the court upon motion by the SEC. The SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in Manhattan, charges Granite, Lalezaria, and M.C. Steel with violating Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4), and with aiding and abetting Canatal's violations of Sections 240(1) and 241(6) and Rule 240(6). The SEC is seeking a final judgment ordering the defendants to disgorge their allegedly ill-gotten gains plus interest, imposing civil penalties, and imposing officer-and-director and penny stock bars against the defendants.  On March 24, 2013, the United States District Court in Manhattan entered a judgment that permanently enjoins the defendants from violating the above-mentioned provisions and orders the parties to pay a civil penalty in the amount of $1,000,000. The court also granted the defendants' motion for leave to amend their answer to include a cross claim against it for contractual indemnification and to recover damages for breach of contract for failure to procure insurance. The Court granted the parties' requests for a temporary restraining order, an asset freeze, and an officer and director bar against them from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, sale, or sale of any security, including the right to reapply for a penny stock bar at any time. The final judgments also order the companies to pay, on a joint and several basis, disgorg
